title: 109_hr1175
content: The Act titled "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2005" addresses the shortage of medical laboratory personnel and outlines programs under the Health Resources and Services Administration to respond to this issue. The "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2005" amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a scholarship and loan repayment program for medical laboratory personnel to alleviate shortages in designated health professional shortage areas. Eligible entities include schools of allied health. Eligible entities for the scholarship and loan repayment program include schools of allied health and health care institution-based programs training medical laboratory personnel. An authorization of appropriations of $11,193,000 in fiscal year 2006 is provided, with additional funding for fiscal years 2007 through 2010. Other programs under Title VII also provide preference in making awards for allied health and other disciplines. The Secretary shall give preference in making awards to assist entities in expanding or establishing programs to increase the number of individuals trained as medical laboratory personnel. Additionally, the Secretary shall develop public service announcements promoting medical laboratory personnel careers and encouraging individuals to enter the field. Authorization of appropriations for these initiatives is provided under the Public Health Service Act. Amendments are made to authorize appropriations for Allied Health and Other Disciplines and Medical Laboratory Personnel training programs under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary is directed to give preference in making awards to expand programs for medical laboratory personnel and promote careers in the field. Authorized appropriations are made for grants or contracts for schools of allied health under the Public Health Service Act. $332,500 is allocated for faculty awards for fiscal year 2006, with additional funding for subsequent years. $8,200,000 is designated for awards to allied health schools for fiscal year 2006, with ongoing funding for future years. The definition of medical laboratory personnel is also clarified in the Act. The term 'medical laboratory personnel' refers to allied health professionals who examine materials from the human body to provide information for diagnosis, prevention, or treatment of diseases. SEC. 1509A addresses the shortage of technologists for laboratory analysis related to screening for cervical cancer. The Secretary will make grants to increase the number of cytotechnologists for cervical cancer screening. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006, with additional funding for 2007-2010. The Secretary will make grants to increase the number of cytotechnologists for cervical cancer screening, with a minimum appropriation of $173,928,000 for the fiscal year. The Public Health Service Act is amended to emphasize training medical laboratory personnel in disciplines with increased personnel needs.
